The HydroChloroFluoroCarbons Phase-out Management Plan (HPMP) for Fiji aims to reduce the use of hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) within the periods 2013 to 2020 and maintain or further reduce their levels for the years thereafter.

For ATLAS Output 1: 1.1: A developed National Bio-fuel Policy. 1.2: Number of revised Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRRs) proposed to enhance implementation of Bio-fuel Policy. 1.3: Number of renewable energy based power generation projects that benefit from Tariff Guarantee Fund.
For ATLAS Output 2: 2.1: Number of clients that request services from the central clearinghouse for their RE-based energy systems project by end of project. 2.2: Number of comprehensive RE resource assessments completed by end of project. 2.3: Number of completed and published new feasibility studies of Independent Power Producer (IPP) investments by end of project.
For ATLAS Output 3: 3.1: Overall installed capacity of RE-based power generation demonstration projects by end of project, MW. 3.2: Endorsed Standard Power Purchase Agreement (SPPA) templates that are used for IPP projects in Fiji. 3.3: Number of prospective investors making enquiries with government agencies. 3.4: A comprehensive report on options and issues related to the establishment of a subsidy fund for private sector renewable energy investment published.
For ATLAS Output 4: 4.1: Percentage of trained Government personnel that are actively engaged in RE-based power generation policy making, planning and implementation, operations and evaluation by end of project. 4.2: Cabinet approved-Electrification Master plan.

comment.narrative: 1.1: Draft Bio-fuel Policy document and Strategic Action Plan; draft Gap Analysis of Existing Legislation and identification of possible new Bio-fuel-related legislation required. 2.1: Draft design of centralized energy database. 3.1: Promotion of, evaluation and confirmation, and baseline data establishment of the demonstration scheme of one of the demonstration projects (i.e. the Bukuya Micro-hydro project). Gender Survey of a bio-fuel demonstration project (Rabi Island). 4.1: Capacity building training planned, designed and conducted for local engineering and consulting firms on the design, installation, and maintenance of RE-based power generation systems.

1.1: Reviewed Bio-fuel Policy document and Strategic Action Plan; draft Gap Analysis of Existing Legislation and identification of possible new Bio-fuel-related legislation required. 1.2: Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRRs) proposed to enhance implementation of Bio-fuel Policy. 1.3: Final report on the design and pilot of De-Risking and Tariff Guarantee Fund for the community-based renewable energy demonstration project (i.e. Bukuya Micro-hydro project). 2.1: An operational Centralized Information Forum established within the Department of Energy. 3.1: Documentation of renewable energy demonstration projects; and design of a sustainable follow-up programme for financially supporting future renewable-energy based power generation in Fiji.

1.1: Approved Bio-fuel Policy document and Strategic Action Plan; and Gap Analysis of Existing Legislation and identification of possible new Bio-fuel-related legislation required. 1.2: Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRRs) proposed to enhance implementation of Bio-fuel Policy. 2.1: Launching of the Renewable Energy Centralized Information Forum (www.reinfofiji.com.fj). 3.1: Finalization of Public Private Partnership (PPP) Agreement between a Special Purpose Company (SPC) and the community Cooperative (in Bukuya, Ba) including the commissioning of pre-payment meters.

To develop the capacity of, and empower, young women and men to be active citizens participate freely in the democratic process. It aims to facilitate the access of young people to political decision making structures and processes.

- Geographical coverage of trainings and programmes conducted to promote accountable leadership of youths - Status of national and sub-national youth organizations with established governance structures

comment.narrative: - Governance training and programmes for youth limited to central division and not available to all provinces - lack of established governance structures at national and sub-national levels for youth organisations' engagement in the decision-making processes at both levels

1. 200 youths with at least 40% females 2. 70% of all new youth officers 3. 200 youths ( with 50% females) 4. Fiji National Youth Report and Pacific Regional youth Report produced and distributed widely 5. At least 5 knowledge products or materials produced

1. 126 youths trained indicated increased level of skills around govenance, leadership and entetreneurship (male:66.6% and female: 33.4%) 2. 14 (20%) new youth administrators were recruited (5 females and 9 males) 3. 273 youths engaged in for livelihood recovery under TC Winston (21% are females) 4. Regional Youth Status report is still progressing and will be published and distributed in 2017 5. 2 knowledge products produced

comment.narrative: 1.1.1: Terrestrial: Sovi basin (16,344 ha); Natewa/ Tunuloa IBA (6,625 ha, with 4437 ha in Tunuloa district) – insecure protection status; Vunivia Catchment: (34 ha). Coastal: Tuva mangroves (710 ha); Rewa delta mangroves (8,636 ha); Labasa mangroves (approx. 3,000 ha), Ba mangroves (4,594 ha); Vunivia mangroves (355 ha). Mangroves are mainly located on state land, inadequately valued and protected by Department of Lands. comment.narrative: 1. Limited Awareness on SDGs in the 5 Pacific Island Countries (PICs) 2. Nil SDGs Workshops at National Level in the 5 PICs 3. Limited SDG Integration into National Development Plans in the 5 PICs 4. Weak National Statistics Systems in the 5 PICs 5. Limited Knowledge Sharing on SDGs in the 5 PICs

1. 1 Regional Awareness Workshop/Campaign on SDGs 2. 5 National Level Workshops/Campaign on SDGs 3. 5 PICs supported in the integration of SDGs into National Development Plans 4. 5 PICs National Statistics Systems strengthened 5. 1 South/South Exchange and 1 Peer Learning Program 6. 1 Regional Program Document designed and finalised

1. UNDP supported Pacific SIDS strengthened data collection for MDG monitoring, to formulate national MDG reports, and to mainstream MDGs into national development plans and strategies.
2. UNDP also facilitated the development of strategic policy interventions targeting priority or off-track MDGs through its MDG Acceleration Framework (MAF);

title.narrative: Youth Empowerment for Sustainable Human development

description.narrative: The IP regional Youth Empowerment for Sustainable Human development draws on the UNDP Youth Strategy 2014–17 & the Pacific Youth Development Framework 2014-23 focusing on increasing youth economic empowerment and civic engagement in decision making.
The IP will focus on decent work and livelihood creation, as well as strengthened engagement in governance at all levels for youths, in Fiji and PNG.

comment.narrative:
Inclusive growth: 1. 30 Urban 2. 50 Rural (30% minimum females - i.e. close to 24 females attended)
Governance: 1. 1 2. 2 (30 % females participation)

Inclusive growth: During Oct'17-Dec'17 period of 3 training sessions, total of 111 individuals attended, but actual 70 were consistent participants. 1. 32 Urban (46% females) 2. 38 Rural (54% females) (Exceeded 30% minimum females - i.e. 35 females attended)
Governance 1. 0 2. 0
Inclusive growth: 1. 30 Urban 2. 50 Rural (30% minimum females - i.e. close to at least 24 females to attend)

Session 4 training (26/2/18-10/3/18) was attended by a total of 94 individuals, with 32 individuals, or 34% of total attendees, being female. Attendance in the urban locations of Nabouwalu and Seaqaqa represented 34% of total attendance with 32 individuals, with the remaining 66% of total attendance, or 62 individuals, attending trainings in the rural areas of Tukavesi and Taveuni. 1. 32 Urban individuals; 2. 62 Rural individuals

description.narrative: Strengthen Fiji's Network of Locally Managed Marine Area (LMMAs) to Support Globally Significant Marine Biodiversity
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Extent to which legal frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which policy frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which institutional frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which capacities to implement national and local plans for Integrated Water Resources Management have improved
Extent to which capacities to protect and restore the health, productivity and resilience of oceans and marine ecosystems, have improved
Strengthen Fiji National Policy and Institutional Framework for a National Marine Protected Area that incorporates LMMAs and demonstrate enhanced management
Environment - policy, planning and administration
1) Fiji is fully engaged in the development and implementation of the Talanoa Facilitative Dialogue and the Climate Action Pacific Partnership;

From November 2017 - November 2018, Fiji will hold the COP Presidence under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) process. This will the first COP Presidency from a small island country that is particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, and therefore it has gathered a lot of attention by Governments, civil society, private sector, academia and the media. The preparation for, and conduct of, a COP Presidency is complex and substantial work, which involves political, technical and organizational aspects. Given the high demands for such a comprehensive

title.narrative: Strengthening Legislatures in the Pacific Countries

description.narrative: Regional programme to strengthen Legislature in Pacific Countries-Federated States of Micronesia,Marshall Islands,Samoa,Solomon Islands,Vanuatu,Fiji. *Note:Fiji component will be under Project 00097051 - Fiji Parliament Support Project -Phase 2.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Extent to which the Parliament has improved its administrative and human resources capacities required to discharge its mandates in relation to law-making, oversight and representation
Number of women participating as candidates in local and national elections supported by UNDP
